intro: Apium inundatum, commonly known as water celery, is a flowering plant native to wetland areas in Europe and Asia. It is characterized by its hollow, aromatic stems and slender, edible leaves that are often used in culinary applications. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the Apiaceae family. Its rhizomes and roots are also harvested for their medicinal and culinary properties. Apium inundatum thrives in moist environments and is often found near ponds, streams, and marshes.
